sn47.10:4.1: Then Venerable Ānanda got dressed in the morning and, taking his bowl and robes, went to the nuns’ quarters,
sn47.10:4.2: and sat down on the indicated seat.
sn47.10:4.3: Then several nuns went up to Venerable Ānanda
sn47.10:4.4: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn47.10:5.1: “Sir, Ānanda, several nuns meditate with their minds firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. They have realized a higher distinction than they had before.”
sn47.10:5.2: “That’s how it is, sisters! That’s how it is, sisters!
sn47.10:5.3: Any monk or nun who meditates with their mind firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation can expect to
sn47.10:5.4: realize a higher distinction than they had before.”
sn47.10:6.1: Then Ānanda educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired those nuns with a Dharma talk, after which he got up from his seat and left.
sn47.10:6.2: Then Ānanda wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to the Buddha,
sn47.10:6.3: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn47.10:6.4: and told him what had happened.
sn47.10:8.1: “That’s so true, Ānanda! That’s so true!
sn47.10:8.2: Any monk or nun who meditates with their mind firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation can expect to
sn47.10:8.3: realize a higher distinction than they had before.
sn47.10:9.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.10:9.3: As they meditate observing an aspect of the body, based on the body there arises physical tension, or mental sluggishness, or the mind is externally scattered.
sn47.10:9.4: That mendicant should direct their mind towards something inspiring.
sn47.10:9.5: As they do so, gladness springs up.
sn47.10:9.7: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.
sn47.10:9.8: When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss.
sn47.10:9.9: And when blissful, the mind comes together in samādhi.
sn47.10:9.11: ‘I have accomplished the goal for which I directed my mind.
sn47.10:9.13: They pull back, and neither place the mind nor keep it connected.
sn47.10:9.14: They understand: ‘I’m neither placing the mind nor keeping it connected. Mindful within myself, I’m happy.’
sn47.10:10.1: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of feelings …
sn47.10:10.3: principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.10:10.4: As they meditate observing an aspect of principles, based on principles there arises physical tension, or mental sluggishness, or the mind is externally scattered.
sn47.10:10.5: That mendicant should direct their mind towards something inspiring.
sn47.10:10.6: As they do so, gladness springs up.
sn47.10:10.8: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.
sn47.10:10.9: When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss.
sn47.10:10.10: And when blissful, the mind comes together in samādhi.
sn47.10:10.12: ‘I have accomplished the goal for which I directed my mind.
sn47.10:10.14: They pull back, and neither place the mind nor keep it connected.
sn47.10:10.15: They understand: ‘I’m neither placing the mind nor keeping it connected. Mindful within myself, I’m happy.’
sn47.10:10.16: That’s how there is directed development.
sn47.10:11.1: And how is there undirected development?
sn47.10:11.2: Not directing their mind externally, a mendicant understands: ‘My mind is not directed externally.’
sn47.10:11.3: And they understand: ‘Over a period of time it’s uncontracted, freed, and undirected.’
sn47.10:11.4: And they also understand: ‘I meditate observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, mindful; I am happy.’
sn47.10:11.5: Not directing their mind externally, a mendicant understands: ‘My mind is not directed externally.’
sn47.10:11.6: And they understand: ‘Over a period of time it’s uncontracted, freed, and undirected.’
sn47.10:11.7: And they also understand: ‘I meditate observing an aspect of feelings, keen, aware, mindful; I am happy.’
sn47.10:11.8: Not directing their mind externally, a mendicant understands: ‘My mind is not directed externally.’
sn47.10:11.9: And they understand: ‘Over a period of time it’s uncontracted, freed, and undirected.’
sn47.10:11.10: And they also understand: ‘I meditate observing an aspect of the mind, keen, aware, mindful; I am happy.’
sn47.10:11.11: Not directing their mind externally, a mendicant understands: ‘My mind is not directed externally.’
sn47.10:11.12: And they understand: ‘Over a period of time it’s uncontracted, freed, and undirected.’
sn47.10:11.13: And they also understand: ‘I meditate observing an aspect of principles, keen, aware, mindful; I am happy.’
sn47.10:11.14: That’s how there is undirected development.
sn47.10:12.1: So, Ānanda, I’ve taught you directed development and undirected development.
sn47.10:12.2: Out of compassion, I’ve done what a teacher should do for the benefit of their disciples.
sn47.10:12.3: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts.
sn47.10:12.4: Practice absorption, mendicants! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later!
sn47.10:12.6: This is my instruction to you.”
sn47.10:13.1: This is what the Buddha said.
sn47.10:13.2: Uplifted, Venerable Ānanda approved of what the Buddha said.
